results.notes:
A single fruiting body growing on the raised sand shoulder of Cooper’s Rd.
Gross morphology can be inferred from the photos. Cap footprint 8 × 7.2 cm; cap thickness above stipe 1 cm; tubes 7-8 mm deep; stipe 6 cm long, 1.6 cm wide at the cap juncture, 1.4 cm wide just below the apex, gradually expanding to 1.9 cm above the base; the asymmetric and lumpy “bulb” 2.3 × 2.7 cm wide. Odor pleasant, fruity.
Specimen preserved + fresh tissue in SDS buffer (vial #102).
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 27-Apr-22):
This collection was sampled for the RNA Polymerase II Second Largest Subunit (rpb2) gene to compare it with the recent studies by Davoodian et al.1,2 The amplified region is between bRPG2-6F3 and bRPG2-7.1R primers (both seen and edited out) and is 775 bps long. The sequencing primers, however, are inside the amplicon, with the reverse primer located “downstream” of the forward one. The forward read is 504 bps long, while the reverse read is 525 bps long, and they share a 254 bps common overlap. The 271 bps “overhang” to the left of the common overlap is from the reverse read and the 250 bps “overhang” to the right is from the forward read. This sequenced gene fragment contains only a single 51 bps intron located between bRPB2-7R2 and bRPG2-7.1R primer areas toward the very end of the amplicon.
This sequence is 98.9~99.8 % similar to 4 accessions labeled as G. subalbellus and 100% similar to one accession called G. roseialbus; the query covers, however, range from only 50% to 79% (due to the differences in the amplified locus regions), with the former number associated with the roseialbus accession. The least similar subalbellus accession has 5 ambiguities, so the actual % similarity is higher. The four subalbellus accessions are associated with the 2018 Gyroporus study by Davoodian et al.1 The roseilabus accession is from the 2020 follow-up study.2 In the second paper, the authors clarify the concept of roseialbus, so the five accessions belong to roseialbus vouchers; unfortunately, the accessions haven’t been edited accordingly. G. subalbellus in the sense of Davoodian et al. is represented by accession FJ536644 derived from a vouch by O.K. Miller (89% similarity % and 90% query cover). To clarify the matter of the two species, Davoodian et al. write:
“[E]xpanding sampling in the residual clade sheds light on the question of whether G. roseialbus Murrill and G. subalbellus Murrill are in fact distinct species. These species were synonymized by Singer (1945), and G. subalbellus has since been the name in use. In the sense of Murrill’s descriptions and type material, G. subalbellus spores are more ovoid to subreniform (~ 7.5–10 × 4–5.5 μm) and the pileus is finely tomentose to nearly glabrous, while G. roseialbus spores are distinctly elongate (~ 11–13 × 4–5 μm) and the pileus is glabrous to nearly so. Other morphological aspects differ as well, such as coloration, but these are somewhat more variable across geographic range and the physical development of the basidiomes. In the light of further sampling in the residual clade, an elusive group with obscure morphology that is echoed by Murrill’s original description of G. subalbellus, it seems clear that G. roseialbus is distinct from G. subalbellus, as indicated in Fig. 1. However, given the diverse and cryptic nature of the residual clade, the exact identity of G. subalbellus is unclear since there are likely more North American species in this clade, and no recent collections have been made from the type locality (Ocean Springs, Mississippi).”
References:
1 Davoodian et al. “A global view of Gyroporus: molecular phylogenetics, diversity patterns, and new species”, Mycologia 110(5), 985–995 (2018)
2 Davoodian et al. “Diversity of Gyroporus (Gyroporaceae, Boletales): rpb2 phylogeny and three new species”, Phytotaxa 434 (3): 208–218 (2020)

results.notes:
Collected at the NJMA foray by unknown participants.
There are three collections here, as shown in the pix. Now I am thinking that the smallest single fruitbody (middle of thumbnail photo) might be another species, but maybe not. Anyway, since I didn’t save that one, the observation concerns the remaining three fruitbodies that are undoubtedly one species.
We’ve been finding these smallish, squat and ungainly typos in the Pine Barrens in the past. Their stipes are almost always drastically tapered to a pointy base, and they don’t smell too good (like a musty cellar). Some of them could be in the T. balloui group (faded caps?) and others I’ve identified as either T. peralbidus or T. rhodoconius sensu Bessette et al. (Boletes of Eastern North America, 2016) based on the appearance of the context. For example, obs 288807, which could be the same species as the present observation, has been tentatively identified by me as T. rhodoconius because of the hyaline marbling of the cut context of this species, as per BENA (it was sequenced, results to be disclosed yet).
results.location_name: Forest Resource Education Center, Jackson Twp., New Jersey, USA

results.notes:
Growing on the bark and decorticated wood of a dead, standing hardwood tree near Tsuga canadensis, Tilia americana. Carpinus caroliniana, Quercus sect. Lobatae, Carya sp., Liriodendron tulipifera, Oxydendron arboreum, Magnolia acuminata, Magnolia tripetala Acer sp. and Rhododendron sp. Caps glabrous with translucent striate margins; convex to pulvinate and umbilicate; 8.3 to 14.5 mm wide and 3.7 to 5.2 mm tall. Gills white and short-decurrent with 1 to 2 tiers of lamellulae. Stems white to pale gray; smooth; hollow; 25.4 to 29.5 mm long and 3.5 to 4.1 mm wide. Odor and taste not distinctive. Spore print white. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Cheilocystidia scattered and fusiform with coralloid apices. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores immediately amyloid, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (5.4) 5.8 – 7 (7.5) × (3.9) 4.3 – 5.1 (5.3) µm; Q = (1.2) 1.22 – 1.5 (1.6); N = 30; Me = 6.3 × 4.7 µm; Qe = 1.4

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 133273840 on September 1, 2022.

results.notes:
Collected by Jacob Kalichman. Growing singly in soil near Tsuga canadensis, Tilia americana. Carpinus caroliniana, Quercus sect. Lobatae, Carya sp., Liriodendron tulipifera, Oxydendron arboreum, Magnolia acuminata, Magnolia tripetala Acer sp. and Rhododendron sp. Cap glabrous and slightly concave; 13.2 mm wide and 3.5 mm tall. Gills white; adnate to short-decurrent; even; with 1 to 2 tiers of lamellulae; slightly intervenose. Stem smooth; smooth; hollow; tapering toward the base; 22.3 mm long and 2.2 mm wide. Cap and stem context white. Odor not distinctive. Pileipellis a hymeniderm. Pileipellis elements with brown intracellular pigment; obovate to clavate; smooth. Pileipellis element measurements: (11.7) 14.6 – 22.3 (25.2) × (7.9) 8.6 – 13.9 (17.4) µm; Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.9 (2.3); N = 30; Me = 17.9 × 11.8 µm; Qe = 1.6. Basidia 1-sterigmate to 4-sterigmate and basally clamped. Basidia measurements: (24.4) 25.8 – 29.6 (30.1) × (6.1) 6.2 – 7.3 (7.6) µm; Q = (3.6) 3.9 – 4.6 (4.8); N = 10; Me = 27.5 × 6.6 µm; Qe = 4.2. Scattered thick-walled dextrinoid present. Spores immediately amyloid, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (4.7) 5.1 – 6.2 (6.6) × (3.3) 3.9 – 4.5 (4.6) µm; Q = (1.1) 1.2 – 1.5 (1.7); N = 30; Me = 5.6 × 4.1 µm; Qe = 1.4.

results.notes:
Location: Near Seaview, WA. On the edge of Pine/Spruce Forest. Near grassy coastal dunes. Growing in clusters.
Substrate: Growing out of moss-covered sand.
Fruit body: .2-.5 cm across. 2-7 cm tall. Cylindrical with round pointed tips. Taller examples were flattened. Lilac colored.
Stipe: Indistinct, hollow.
Flesh: Thin, fragile, concolorous.
Odor: Mild.
Taste: Mild.
results.location_name: Seaview, Pacific Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Location: Near Seaview, WA. Mixed coastal Pine/Spruce Forest. Growing solitary or in scattered clumps.
Substrate: Growing out of duff.
Cap: 8-19cm in diameter. Round, broadly convex, plane, and uplifted caps seen. Bright rad to orange in color. Viscid. Universal veil warts. Sulcate margin.
Gills: Close. Free. White.
Stipe: 8-13cm long; 2-4cm thick. Straight. The bulb is egg shaped. Upper stipe is white. The lower stipe is cream colored. Solid.
Partial Veil: While hanging skirt.
Volva: Whitish scaly rings on the bottom of stipe.
Flesh: Firm. White.
Odor: None.
Taste: Mild.
results.location_name: Seaview, Pacific Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Location: Near Seaview, WA. On the edge of mixed coastal Pine/Spruce Forest. Near grassy coastal dunes.
Substrate: Growing out of moss covered sand.
Cap: .3 – 2.5cm in diameter. Conic to Convex with a slight umbo. Smooth surface. Chestnut or ochre in color. Strongly bruising blue. Margin even with some erosion for larger specimens. Incurved margin. Striated. Fibrilose annular zone in upper region of stipe.
Gills: Ascending. Adnate. Light brown and stained to black where injured. Close and two-tiered. Edges whitish.
Stipe: 2-5cm tall. .1-.2cm thick. Silky white to brownish at base. Thickens at base. Curved at base with white aerial tufts of mycelium.
Odor: None.
Taste: Bitter.
results.location_name: Seaview, Pacific Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
Location: Near Seaview, WA. On the edge of mixed coastal Pine/Spruce Forest. Near grassy coastal dunes. Solitary.
Substrate: Growing out of duff.
Cap: 10-11cm in diameter. Domed. Tan to ochre. Viscid.
Pores: Small. Straw yellow.
Tubes: Sunken near stipe.
Stipe: 8-13cm long; 3-6 cm thick. Widening at base. Club shaped at base. Light brown and darkening in the middle. Fine white reticulum at apex.
Flesh: Thick and firm. No bruising noticed.
Odor: Indistinct.
Taste: Almond.

results.notes:
This bright. late-season Suillus was found among sphagnum moss in a swamp, under larch, red maple, ash, alder, birch, etc.
Cap about 55 mm across.
No strong bruising noted. Flavor (dried) mild.
Spore print dark purplish brown.
I waivered about this possibly being spectabilis, which was abundant there this season, as the only spectabilis spore print (pink) seemed wrong and none of the spectabilis were so yellow orange. Now I suspect my spectabilis spore print was pink/pale because it was scant, and I see it reported to be purplish brown. My cap color also matches well with that of 386738. And I have not found any better matches.
Collection made.

results.notes:
I was drawn by the ‘cheap thrill’ of Dacrymyces near the base of the trunk of a large wind-thrown larch (with bark, in a swamp). Then I noticed the dried mushrooms interspersed, but failed to see their interesting variably woolly stipe detail until reviewing photos.
The cap of the thumbnail specimen, as seen in profile, is about 17 mm across.
Searching several other large wind-thrown larch nearby failed to turn up further specimens.
On October 30 I returned and collected several. The round cap shown face-on in three photos was about 15 mm across dry and expanded to about 20 mm when wetted. I show cap and gills in rehydrated state. The wetted cap left a white watermark deposit on foil, washed out spores, I assume. None of the specimens appears to show mold growth (unless that is what produced the stipe ‘ornamentation’).
This is on the same tree (in fact intermingled) as 479725.
See also 496392 for 2022.

results.notes:
Collected with Jacob Kalichman. Growing on the bark of a live Quercus sect. Quercus toward the base of the tree. Growing with Hydropus sp. (DG2108218), cf. Delicatula sp. (DG2108219), Hydropus omphaliiformis, cf. Gymnopus sp. and Clitopilus sp. Caps convex to pulvinate with depressed centers; some with a small umbo; smooth; dry; 3.8 to 14.5 mm wide and 1.9 to 5.8 mm tall. Gills decurrent; even; with 1 to 2 tiers of lamellulae; slightly intervenose. ~15 full-length lamellae reaching the stems. Stems pubescent; stuffed in young basidiocarps and becoming hollow; 4.6 to 13.0 mm long and 0.6 to 1.4 mm wide. Cap and stem context white. Surfaces not fluorescing. Odor and taste not distinctive. Clamps present in all tissues. Pileipellis a cutis. Caulocystidia abundant, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore print white. Lamellar trama inamyloid and hyaline. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Spores immediately inamyloid and remaining so after 1 hr 20 min; hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (6.3) 6.4 – 7.7 (8.1) × (4) 4.1 – 5 (5.5) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.6 (1.7); N = 30; Me = 7 × 4.7 µm; Qe = 1.5.

results.notes:
Growing in soil among moss under Tsuga candensis at the edge of a trail. Caps hygrophanous. Basal mycelium white. Odor not distinctive. All surfaces fluorescing yellowish green. Pileipellis a cutis. Clamps absent in pileipellis and lamellae. Lamellar cystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (21.2) 23.3 – 28.4 (29) × (6.1) 6.7 – 8 (8.3) µm; Q = (2.8) 3.1 – 4.1 (4.7); N = 15; Me = 26.1 × 7.3 µm; Qe = 3.6. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (5.3) 5.6 – 7.1 (8.8) × (3.3) 3.9 – 4.7 (5.7) µm; Q = (1.2) 1.3 – 1.6 (2); N = 30; Me = 6.4 × 4.3 µm; Qe = 1.5

—

Mirrored on iNaturalist as observation 133275208 on September 1, 2022.

results.notes:
Learning how to properly identify with microscope.
Very wet area, with a varying mixed woods surrounding.
Body of water near by.
Found most directly at edge of standing water in low spots on spagnum moss often … near hard wood often and in wet muddy bottoms or drainage areas.
Growing single y and in groups.
I believe the young specimens are yellow ish and the gills start off light tan n become dark brown n black with a slight white edge on gills. The stipe seems to be weak in age asnaps abruptly when breaks. This location is the only place that I have found this exact variation of this species. The stipe seems to have a fairly regular blue hugh to the foot. Hard to see in pic. I feel like it’s oviously looking like a lib but I’m questioning if maybe it’s a blue foot.? Or variation of the two?

results.notes:
It’s interesting how the darkness of spore prints for L. nuda varies. In some cases the print is very pale, possibly mistaken for white. (I have read accounts where the print is reported as “white”.) Recently, a member of our local club collected what she IDed as L. nuda (the photo posted online appeared to confirm the ID). The spore print color she got seemed very dark.
I then collected some L. nuda which I printed. Four collections(A, B, C, D) made from the same location produced fairly pigmented prints. But in one case the print featured distinctly contrasting lighter and darker areas. I think this may be due to moisture being drawn out of the specimen where the print appears darker.
Photos of print(s) are: ABCD followed by the one print showing the contrasting saturation of color.

results.notes:
Wide grassy/mossy trail with gray birch along the borders. Up until a few years ago this location had produced many gray-capped Leccinum msuhrooms that exhibited varying degrees/hues of staining on the cut context. After many of the overhanging birch trees trees were cut down to make the trail accessible to PA State Game Commission vehicles, the Leccinum mushrooms disappeared completely until this year.
Solitary specimen groeing near birch.
Cut context slowly stained pink in the upper stipe and spotty blue in the base. There appears to be a Hypomyces crawling up the stipe.
Spores from drop are ~13-18 × 4-5.
Compare with obs 474914 . Spore dimensions and staining reaction are different. This present fruit body was found in the same location and same habitat as 474914.

results.notes:
Growing scattered in leaf litter on a hillside near Fagus grandifolia, Acer saccharum, Tsuga canadensis, Quercus rubra, Quercus alba, Pinus sp. and Betula sp. Locally abundant. Caps dry and glabrous; some slightly umbonate; 12.8 to 33.7 mm wide and 6.9 to 10.3 mm tall. Stems dry and smooth; 23.8 to 34.1 mm long and 2.0 to 4.2 mm wide. Basal mycelium white. Stem bases attached to white rhizomorphs. Strong farinose odor. Taste farinose. Clamps present in the lamellar trama. Basidia up to 4-sterigmate. Spores inamyloid, hyaline, smooth and thin-walled. Spore measurements: (4.3) 5.8 – 6.9 (8) × (2.8) 3.2 – 4 (4.3) µm; Q = (1.3) 1.6 – 2 (2.4); N = 26; Me = 6.3 × 3.5 µm; Qe = 1.8

results.notes:
Growing singly in soil among leaf litter on a hillside near Fagus grandifolia, Acer saccharum, Tsuga canadensis, Quercus rubra and Quercus alba. Cap weakly zonate; 76.8 mm wide and 24.3 mm tall; fluorescing green except for an orange spot at the center. Gills fluorescing orange. Stem dry; scrobiculate; 58.4 mm long and 17.2 mm wide; fluorescing orange. Latex white. Stem surface, context and cut gills staining purple. Context white. Odor not distinctive. Taste slightly bitter. Spores amyloid and spiny. Spore measurements (including spines): (8) 9.6 – 12 (12.9) × (7.8) 8.2 – 10.7 (11.2) µm; Q = 1 – 1.19 (1.2); N = 30; Me = 10.5 × 9.4 µm; Qe = 1.1

Precipitación mínima de 15 – 25 mm en los meses de enero y diciembre, precipitación máxima 350 mm y 300 mm en los meses de mayo, junio y julio; con menos de 60 mm de lluvia en el mes más seco y precipitación anual superior a 1270 mm. Cuenta con valores mínimos de humedad relativa a inicio del año (65%), y valores más altos en junio, julio, agosto y septiembre (90-85%). Cuenta con una altura sobre el nivel del mar entre 0 y 1000 m, una pluviosidad entre 2000 y 4000 mm y temperatura promedio mayor de 24 °C, con amplitud de temperatura máxima de 8 °C, como se referencia en DANE. Los máximos valores de temperatura no sobrepasan los 36 °C y los mínimos valores no logran bajar los 19 °C que se presentan en febrero y en julio, respectivamente. Temperatura media anual mayor de 20 °C, con una estación seca y una lluviosa bien definidas (Bustamante et al., 2017; DANE, 1999; Castro y Sosa, 2017).

Se observa con frecuencia plantas representativas de la zona como Yarumo (Cecropia peltata), Jobo (Spondias mombin), Cedro (Cedrela odorata), Nauno (Albizzia guachepele), Cañafistol (Cassia moschata), Flor blanco (Tabebuia orinocensis), Uña de gato (Cynodon dactylon), entre otras.
